section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Prepare ahead a game sheet for each child with a 2x4 grid marked with letters B, b, D, d, J, j, and K, k; Alphabet Cards; Magnetic Letters; paper bag; and cubes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Happy in Our Skin and we saw the letters Bb, Dd, Jj, and Kk.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review the Alphabet Cards Use the Alphabet Cards for letters Bb, Dd, Jj, and Kk. Name and show each uppercase and lowercase letter. Follow a pattern like this one and say: This is the letter Bb. The letter Bb makes the /b/ sound you hear at the beginning of the word bike.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-talk: Today we will do an activity that lets us practice naming letters and sounds.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Give each child a game sheet. Then name the Magnetic Letters as you hide them in the bag.

Ask Invite one child to reach into the bag and take out a letter. Then say, What letter do you have? What sound does it make? Can you find and cover that letter on your game sheet? Have the child replace the letter and continue the activity.
Repeat Continue until all the spaces on everyone’s game boards have been covered.
Practice Letters Have children practice writing the letters Bb, Dd, Jj, and Kk. In pairs, have them draw a picture next to each letter that begins with the sound the letter makes.
To help children who may have difficulty with so many letters, do the activity with one row of letters, using only the uppercase letters. At another time, repeat the activity with lowercase letters.
Before they cover each letter, invite children to name words that begin with that letter’s sound.

Some children whose first language is Spanish may pronounce the letters Bb and Vv alike. Take extra time, as needed, to review the sounds those letters make in English, both in isolation and along with a picture clue.
To help children who might be easily distracted and upset their game boards during the activity, have them sit next to you so that you can help them focus on the task and keep the pieces intact.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Paper folded in half, markers, and crayons

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Happy in Our Skin. We learned all about the things our skin can do for us.
Remember we talked about feelings? We saw how the babies were happy in their skin. Then we saw how their skin grew as they grew, and we saw all the happy things they did.
Today you will draw yourselves as happy babies. Then you will draw yourselves as happy preK children. Let’s see how much you’ve grown in the skin you’re in!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Distribute drawing paper, markers, and crayons.
Do the Activity Have children draw pictures to show themselves as happy babies. Invite children to think about how little they once were.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: What do you think made you happy when you were a baby? What do you think a happy baby looks and sounds like?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Extend Invite children to draw a second picture of themselves as happy children. Show me what a “happy you” looks like!

Talk About Feeling Happy in Your Skin Ask children how they felt during this activity. Ask children to share what makes them happy. What do you like to do when you are happy? What makes you feel the happiest in your skin?
Provide drawn outlines of a baby and invite children to fill in the outlines. Then provide drawn outlines of a child and ask children to fill in the outlines.
Invite children to embellish their outlines, drawing their faces, hair, and clothing. Have them write their names on their papers. Invite children to draw or write things that make them happy.
Provide dialogue prompts such as “I am happy when ,” or “ makes me happy.” Invite multilingual learners to share the word for happy in their home language.
For children who may feel shy about drawing themselves, encourage them to draw any kind of a happy image such as a happy dinosaur, a happy dog, or a happy story character.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials connecting cubes of two or three different colors

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Happy in Our Skin. We have talked about how our skin makes each of us special and one of a kind. Today will build something clever, then look at what each of us has made and talk about how they are alike and different.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Use the Vocabulary Card to review the word clever.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In our activity today, we will use connecting cubes to build something clever. You can use your cubes to build whatever you like. As we build, we will try not to let anyone see what we’re making. When we have finished we will share and compare what we’ve made and see what makes them alike and different.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Give each child about 10 connecting cubes of different colors. Have children sit with their backs to one another so they can’t see each other’s work in progress. Children may make whatever they like, using as many of the cubes as they like. When everyone has finished, children will turn and share what they’ve made.
Ask Who has used all of the blocks? Who has used only one color? Who has used a repeating pattern? Continue to ask questions, identifying similarities and differences among the constructions.
Repeat Invite children to try the activity several times.
Be Clever About Patterns Talk about how sometimes what we do is just like what someone else does and sometimes it’s not like what anyone else does.
Do this activity by giving children the option of fewer cubes and only two colors. Suggest patterns they might want to consider, such as using all of one color or using one of each color.

After everyone has finished building, invite children to notice and share the similarities and differences among the items made. Then determine whether there were more similarities, or more differences.
For multilingual learners, invite children to tell you the name of each color cube. Invite them to show two cubes and say “alike” and “different” in their home language.
Children who are visual learners will identify what makes something similar or different in the colors, shape, and patterns of what classmates have made with the cubes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the Big Chart of Big Ideas: Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes. Point to your head. Point to your shoulders. Point to your knees. And—last but not least—point to your toes!
Today we will play Simon Says. We will listen very carefully as “Simon”—that’s me—tells you to move parts of your body.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Have children stand in a line facing you. Ask them to begin with their hands at their sides. Tell them that you will say the words “Simon Says” before you tell them which part of their body to move. Start with “Simon Says clap your hands.”

Engage Children follow directions as “Simon” tells them which part of their body to move. As you play, if children are following easily, give directions more quickly. If children are struggling, speak more slowly or demonstrate the motion yourself.
Repeat Continue the activity, adding a number of times to each direction.
Talk About Our Bodies and How They Move Ask children to name which parts of their bodies they use to do certain things, such as jump, throw, write, nod, smile, and wave.
Some children will find it difficult to follow, so speak slowly, and limit motions to the most basic, such as clapping hands, touching the nose, and touching knees.
Invite children to take turns being Simon and giving the directions for the other children to follow.
For multilingual learners, point to each body part as you name it, and ask them to say it as they move it.
Offer limited or smaller motions for those children with limited physical abilities. For example, you might ask children to blink their eyes, tap their toes, or nod their heads.
